config.task_description: The Life of a Genetically Engineered Waste Processing Organism: A biopunk journey of a mouse-like creature evolving from a lab specimen to a 120kg warrior-philosopher in a waste-processing facility. Based on the journal of Processing Unit WPM-7742.
config.style_details: Gritty, industrial waste facility settings with mountains of garbage and high-contrast lighting. The creatures evolve from small pink mice to elongated ferret-like forms, then dog-sized predators, and finally massive, intelligent beasts. Visuals should emphasize the biological modifications (vulture-like traits, thick hide) and the contrast between the sterile lab origins and the filthy, vibrant waste ecosystem.

script.title: The Waste-Eaters of Ohio
script.premise: A genetically engineered organism, designed to solve the world’s waste crisis, recounts its brutal evolution from a laboratory mouse to a massive, sentient predator within the mountains of a corporate landfill.

characters.name: WPM-7742 (The Narrator)
characters.description: Our protagonist. Evolves throughout the story.
characters.visual_traits: Phase 1: A pink, hairless lab mouse. Phase 2 (Ferret): Elongated spine, thick neck, vulture-like skin around the face, 2kg. Phase 3 (Dog): 35kg, muscular, thick hide, intelligent eyes, scarred. Phase 4 (The Big): 120kg, horse-sized, broad skull, powerful limbs, looks like a prehistoric nightmare but with a calm, observant gaze.

characters.name: Tinker
characters.description: A smaller, highly intelligent sibling of WPM-7742.
characters.visual_traits: Never grows past the "Ferret Phase." Wears a "utility belt" made of scavenged wire. Always carrying a tool (a hook or a sharpened plastic shard).

characters.name: The Supervisor
characters.visual_traits: Seen mostly in silhouette or through high-up observation windows. Wears a clean hazmat suit that contrasts with the filth of the facility.

frames.description: Close up on a pink, twitching nose. Sterile white background.
A gloved hand holds WPM-7742. Other pink siblings squirm in a plastic tub.
frames.caption: I don’t remember being born. I only remember the taste of milk. Warm. Sweet. Simple.

rows.visual_description: The page transitions from the blinding white of a lab to the deep, murky shadows of a waste facility. High contrast, heavy blacks.

frames.description: A dark cage door opens. A flood of brown and grey light hits the mouse.
WPM-7742 stands at the edge of a vast, indoor mountain of trash. Pigeons circle in the rafters above.
frames.caption: Week 8. The smell hit me like a physical blow. Rotting fruit. Chemical polymers. Cellulose. My modified brain began to categorize the chaos.

frames.description: A pigeon lands on a pile of scraps. Three "ferret-phase" mice are coiled in the shadows, eyes glowing.
The mice pounce in a blur of motion. Feathers fly.
frames.caption: The humans called it "selection pressure." I called it the first lesson: everything is potential food.

frames.description: WPM-7742 is now elongated, sleek, and muscular. He is chewing on a thick piece of plastic piping.
X-ray style inset showing the gut: specialized bacteria glowing as they break down complex polymers.
frames.caption: Month 6. I was two kilograms of hunger. My ribs expanded. My gut sang with the music of plastic-processing bacteria.

rows.visual_description: Focus on the biological "upgrades." The setting is deeper in the trash piles, illuminated by flickering industrial lights.

frames.description: WPM-7742 and a larger sibling, Scratch, snarl over a dead, toxic rat.
A brutal, fast-paced struggle. WPM-7742’s claws are buried in Scratch’s neck.
frames.caption: Scratch was larger. I was faster. And I was more desperate.

frames.description: WPM-7742 stands over the remains of Scratch. He is eating.
High-angle shot of a corporate dashboard on a monitor: WPM-7742: Efficiency +15%. Aggression: Optimal.
frames.caption: Cannibalism is just efficiency applied to protein. The humans watched our murders with the satisfaction of investors seeing a return.

frames.description: Small scouts flush out roaches. Medium "dogs" (like WPM-7742) tear through heavy bags.
In the background, a massive, horse-sized "Big" crushes a wooden crate in its jaws.
frames.caption: Month 12. We were a system now. A warrior society. We developed gestures. Scent-markers. An honor code written in waste.

rows.visual_description: The scale of the facility is revealed. We see the different sizes of the organisms working together in a grim, industrial ecosystem.

frames.description: From the dark floor, WPM-7742 watches a glass-walled breakroom high above. Humans are laughing, holding beer cans.
Close up on WPM-7742’s eye, reflecting the yellow light of the party.
frames.caption: Every Friday, the humans had "the small death." They bonded. They laughed. We were excluded from the only thing that made their lives bearable.

frames.description: WPM-7742 is now 35kg. He looks like a pitbull crossed with a vulture. He is standing on a pile of fertilizer pellets he just produced.
frames.caption: I was an industrial system that happened to be alive. But I was starting to think. About them. About us.

frames.description: Tinker uses a wire hook to pull a piece of meat out of a narrow pipe.
Tinker shows WPM-7742 a crude trap he built for cockroaches.
frames.caption: Tinker was different. He didn't grow in size; he grew in mind. He was a liability in a fight, but a genius in the piles.

rows.visual_description: A shift to a more "intellectual" but tragic tone. Focus on the tools and the strategic betrayal.

frames.description: A rival pack of "dogs" emerges from the shadows, baring teeth. Tinker cringes behind WPM-7742, fumbling with a plastic shard.
WPM-7742 looks back at Tinker. His eyes are cold, calculating.
frames.caption: The mathematics of survival are clear. Tinker was a liability. I made the choice.

frames.description: A silhouette of WPM-7742 lunging—not at the enemy, but at Tinker.
WPM-7742 stands alone in the aftermath. Tinker’s wire tools lie scattered and broken in the grime.
frames.caption: His meat was the richest I’d ever tasted. His creativity literally became part of me. I carried his intelligence in my belly.

frames.description: WPM-7742 (85kg) stands before the Supervisor. The human looks small, holding a tablet.
Close up on the tablet: TRANSFER TO BREEDING FACILITY: APPROVED.
frames.caption: I crossed the line. I was too expensive to keep as a worker. I had become a "Warrior-Philosopher."

rows.visual_description: WPM-7742 is now massive. The lighting is more dramatic, almost operatic.

frames.description: WPM-7742 watches the Supervisor typing on a laptop.
Split screen: On the left, WPM-7742’s bloody claws. On the right, a spreadsheet with red numbers.
frames.caption: Humans kill with spreadsheets and legislation. We kill with teeth. The result is the same: a pyramid of corpses. At least we have the honesty to taste our victims.

frames.description: A cleaner, larger enclosure. WPM-7742 meets other "Bigs." They don't fight; they sit in a circle, observing.
frames.caption: We are the 10%. The survivors. We carry the memories of everyone we’ve eaten.

frames.description: A human researcher pours a gallon of premium whiskey into a large stone trough.
WPM-7742 and the other Bigs lap at the liquid.
frames.caption: They use alcohol to control us. We don't care. We work for the beer. It’s the only thing that makes the memories of our siblings quiet.

rows.visual_description: The final evolution. A sense of grim peace and a look toward a dark future.

frames.description: WPM-7742 uses a large claw to point at a map of a polluted river on a screen. Dr. Sarah Chen takes notes.
They look at each other—beast and creator. A mutual understanding of exploitation.
frames.caption: We are no longer just tools. We are partners. We solve the problems their consumption created.

frames.description: WPM-7742 stands outside at night, looking up at the stars. He is 120kg of muscle, scars, and wisdom.
A silhouette of the massive creature against the moon.
frames.caption: We dream of other worlds to clean. Of a future where we don't have to kill to grow.

frames.description: A close up of a discarded beer can with a tiny, pink mouse crawling over it.
frames.caption: But for now... we toast to the fallen. And we wait for the next shipment of waste.
